reasoning: The critique targets a load-bearing step in the paper’s case that (on unbounded linear views) achieving a mostly-great future is a narrow target because value-per-resource is fat-tailed: it argues that fat-tailedness can also create a large “search dividend” when an advanced civilization can do massive parallel experimentation, so rarity of top configurations need not imply low discoverability. This is moderately central: it bears on one of the paper’s key reasons for ‘specific use’ fussiness in §3.2, but the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ thesis also rests on other independent supports (eutopia fragility/multiplicative factors, scale requirements, bads-dominance in bounded-separate aggregation, etc.), so refuting this wouldn’t collapse the whole position. Strength is moderate because the order-statistics point is real and would force the paper to model sampling/search capacity and incentives, but it does not by itself show that high-value uses are discoverable/implementable under the paper’s own conditioning (limited de dicto optimization), nor does it address hardness/coordination/incentive-misalignment reasons why search might not locate or deploy the extreme-tail configuration. Correctness is fairly high: the general mathematical intuition about maxima under heavy tails and parallel search is right, though the critique overreaches in implying this flips the conclusion without additional assumptions. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: "Fat-tail search benefits offset 'astronomical space' challenge"
